item.title: Stop observing, start making
item.description: Observability has become the read-it-everywhere buzzword of software development. Like others before it. Observing any piece of technology is incredibly easy. Look at your screen, intensely. Do it some more. You are observing technology. If it’s on, you are observing software too. So what now? You basically know nothing more about your system now that you did before observing it (except for, is it on ðŸ”¥?). The reason why observing a piece of software is just a useless exercise is because observability is not an action.

item.title: asdf, little awesome tool
item.description: Some years ago I discovered a little tool with a huge potential. I started using it and since then it proved useful in so many ways it’s now a mandatory tool in my toolset. This tool is asdf. asdf is a CLI tool version manager. You may already be using multiple ones (rbenv, nvm, goenv to name a few) to manage versions of programming language tooling and accessories.
